book_name: An Elegant Puzzle - Systems of Engineering Management - by Will Larson.pdf
summary: In this chapter, the author emphasizes the importance of recognizing and addressing broken systems in project management. Projects often fail gradually due to accumulating technical debt and poor decisions. To reset a broken system, one must acknowledge past failures and take responsibility, which can build trust within the team. However, not everyone has the power to enforce change; sometimes, stepping back and allowing the system to collapse can ultimately lead to a more effective reset. Acknowledging mistakes and learning from them is crucial for progress and improvement.

slides.section_body: Managing projects requires awareness of the stocks and flows within systems. Understanding how projects fall behind and accumulate technical debt takes time and a strategic mindset. Recognizing these patterns allows us to address failures systematically.
slides.quote: Projects fail slowly—and fixing them takes time, too.

slides.section_body: Working frantically on projects can feel productive, but it rarely counters deep-rooted issues. Real progress comes from acknowledging the time lost to poor implementation rather than just exerting effort.
slides.quote: Hard work doesn't always lead to success; awareness does.

slides.section_body: To initiate a reset, one must be willing to take responsibility for the project’s failures. This can foster trust and lead to a healing process within the team, setting the stage for new goals.
slides.quote: Taking the blame fosters trust and paves the way for healing.

slides.section_body: Not everyone is in a position to enforce policies. However, real influence can help facilitate a reset by guiding teams toward recovery and new objectives.
slides.quote: With influence, we can guide the team even without authority.

slides.section_body: Sometimes, allowing a flawed system to collapse can be the best form of reset. Band-aid solutions can prolong suffering; stepping back may conserve energy for future successes.
slides.quote: A deeply flawed system can't be saved by band-aids.

slides.section_body: Retreating from a failing system can be challenging, especially for diligent individuals. However, this pause may allow for regrouping and preparing for a healthier structure post-reset.
slides.quote: Conserve your energy for the next, more functional system.

slides.section_body: Mistakes are inevitable, but failure to acknowledge them leads to compounding problems. Embracing errors quickly is essential for learning and growth.
slides.quote: Acknowledge errors quickly to avoid burnout and stagnation.

slides.section_body: Each failure provides valuable lessons. By cutting losses earlier, we can learn and navigate toward more effective paths in our projects.
slides.quote: Learn from mistakes and pivot to new strategies.

slides.section_body: Stop idealizing hardworking individuals who push through mistakes. Instead, recognize that relinquishing the hero mentality can lead to more effective outcomes.
slides.quote: Kill your heroes and learn to move forward.

slides.section_body: Resetting a broken system is uncomfortable but necessary. Embrace the journey of change and transformation to foster a resilient and adaptable team environment.
slides.quote: Embrace discomfort; it’s part of the journey toward growth.
